title: Why Redemption and Locket are toxic and centralizing, with math
body:
{{item:3107}} : 150 - 490 healing based on *target* level

{{item:3190}} : 70 - 665 decaying shield based on *your* level

Both items work with heal/shield power

Ideal scenario: Level 18 ({{item:3107}} + {{item:3504}} + {{item:3222}} + {{item:3190}}) = ((490 + (490 x .4)) + (665 + (665 x .4))) x 5 = 8085 effective sustain in a level 18 team fight with actives alone.

Less ideal: Level 18 ({{item:3107}} + {{item:3504}} + {{item:3222}} + {{item:3190}}) = ((490 + (490 x .4)) + (665 + (665 x .4))) x 2 or 3 = 3234 to 4851 effective sustain in a level 18 team fight from actives alone on about half your team.

Less ideal version 2: Level 18 ({{item:3107}} + {{item:3190}}) = ((490 + (490 x .1)) + (665 + (665 x .1))) x 5 = 6352 effective sustain in a level 18 team fight with minimal heal/shield stacking.

Less ideal version 2.5: Level 18 ({{item:3107}} + {{item:3190}}) = ((490 + (490 x .1)) + (665 + (665 x .1))) x 2 or 3 = 2541 to 3811 effective sustain in a level 18 team fight with actives alone with minimal heal/shield stacking on half your team.

Now, I know that a support's level is going to be harder to build than anyone else, so obviously Redemption's values in an in-game scenario will lean towards the higher end of the spectrum than Locket's, and no, getting to level 18 isn't a guarantee every match, but here's the case in point: THIS IS A LOT OF EFFECTIVE HEALTH. Even without heal/shield stacking, it's a shit ton of effective health. There's a difference between wanting supports to feel meaningful and *how you do it*. This isn't encouraging support players to engage in the match and feel important. This is encouraging pressing 2 number buttons and giving your team like 2 tanks worth of health over the five of them *before considering the champion's  own possible sustain options*. It makes sense, too, since Riot was trying to find out how they'd make supports not fall off by late game. This, however, is a stupid way to do it, and I'm a support main.

REMOVE these types of actives. Support will always be centralized around Locket as long as it's an aoe shield, and instead of *learning this*, Riot essentially made TWO LOCKETS. What on this green Earth is the name of the drug they were utilizing when coming up with these decisions, cause I wanna add it to my bucket list.

So how do you accomplish that?

Remove ward limits: Glorified ward dispensers.
Supporty aura-esque items: Glorified trinket collectors.
Making their kits strong enough to hold their own without xp and gold: They become too strong and create the most uninteractive solo lanes imaginable when they DO get access to xp and gold.

I honestly think the aura-christmas-tree idea sounds like the healthiest so far. You get to make strategic choices for the team based on what you're facing which seems like a fitting activity for the support position, the items can be balanced around only being strong on supports due to a lack of raw kit-enhancing stats that other champions want to buy to take advantage of their scaling.

I think the problems with this concept now are just:
A) Locket and Redemption are fairly similar in their optimal scenarios. (Everyone is clustered together? Better press this button and hope its numbers are big enough to make a difference!) Everyone is kinda forgetting about the other options so it feels like we aren't actually hitting the 'strategic choice' goal yet.
B) Locket and Redemption are the standout options for this class of item at the moment. You generally build both of them and the only question is "in what order?" so there's little game-to-game diversity.
C) Locket, Redemption, and most other items that fall into this category are active items which are simply a pain in the ass to use, which is compounded as you get more and more active items increasing the complexity of your backpack. Say what you want about the un-interactive-ness of the old Aegis aura, but there was something comforting about seeing it in your inventory and knowing "This means I'm helping the team out right now!" without having to constantly remember to watch for a moment to use it.

IMO, Banner of Command and Zz'rot portal show the most potential for good "support" out-of-combat utility items as actives are way less stressful to use in out-of-combat situations while Zeke's Herald and Ardent Censer show the most potential for good in-combat items as they provide unique, benefical combat effects without adding more buttons for the player to remember during the most stressful part of a game.

As an assassin who's job it is to murder the carry or support, redemption pisses me off. I just wish that it couldn't be used while dead because as an assassin in the past my thought is "Kill Raka, Sona or Nami then kill the carry after" but i can't do that because redemption let's you use it while dead which effectively makes every assassin that's not a Skirmisher too, completely useless. 

I can deal with the massive heal, but if i have to deal with a 3000+ effective health ADC, you can deal with an assassin that can kill you because that's my job to remove key components from a fight without dying myself. 

All in all i do think the item was needed but 3 things should be removed.

1. Should not be able to be used while dead because it makes removing the Support from a fight pointless.
2. Should not deal damage because there isn't a point 
3. This item is core on EVERY SINGLE support, a core item isn't 2100, it's 2600+ and for the amount of things it does, it should definitely be that price or much higher because i have never seen a support have to wait to get this item, they back once in lane and have it and that's not how a core item works.

Having an action to use while dead is interesting though. It's a different experience, but a fun one. It's less tilting to die now because you are still focused on the game and waiting for the right spot and time to heal, instead of just raging at your team for failing you. As a support, not tilting is very important.

It's not fun for everyone else, infact it ruins the fun for many, fun doesn't matter in competitive. When an entire class is made borderline useless because another one has a specific item that's not fun, that's broken. 

You shouldn't tilt from a death anyway, if you can tilt from a death you shouldn't play support because statistically you'll be dying more than anyone else on your team and there's good reason for that. Killing a support is extremely important for winning a teamfight right now and that's kind of cool considering Redemption made it so you can't ignore them like you used to. The fact of the matter is though that it doesn't matter if you kill them, they still get rewarded by being able to help while dead. The fact that it's more important than ever to remove a Support from the fight now, coupled with the fact that it doesn't matter if you do or not because redemption is useable while dead. Put's the enemy team in a no win situation, if they kill you they won't remove you from the fight anyway, but they have to kill you because if they don't you'll win the fight anyway.

Rememption does not need to be useable while dead, it's frustrating and makes an entire other class pointless unless their broken as fuck.

"If you can tilt from a death you shouldn't play support anyway"

Riot has made it so at least 20% of the people playing support don't want to play it. Autofill, remember?
If you nerf Locket (again) or Redemption without buffing anything else for supports, both ADC and Support will be truly useless and make an even less of an impact on the game they already are.

That's the thing though, supports can't be buffed because those items exist.

Supports are currently stuck in a position that is not item-reliant but also has access to some of, if not the most powerful active items in the game.

Stop making supports rely on Actives to be relevant. As long as powerful actives exists, the support meta is always gonna be "who can use the active better" and the random mage or two. Once those are removed, Riot can finally look into giving them much stronger/unique kits. 

Once those reworks are done, they can look into giving supports more xp through items instead, having them rely a lot more on their own raw scaling utility and stats rather than hoping they somehow snowball for some reason.

I feel the issue is a bit more nuanced than that, though: currently, we're at a stage where support item actives are making the individual champions practically irrelevant, but the actives themselves are fun and feel powerful. For sure, they could use a nerf, but beyond that, the real problem with support itemization is that it doesn't enhance the power of support kits themselves. The healing and shielding passive is a good start, but it only covers a small subset of what supports can do, and we still have far too many support items saddled with unsatisfying amounts of defensive stats and regen, instead of stats that are more directly beneficial to enchanters. 

I'd like to keep those item actives, but I also want to see support items truly empower the champions they're catering to, instead of just giving them tons of regen they don't necessarily want while they wait to build up towards the mandatory item actives. It's not a good sign to see tanky support items like Locket and Redemption become essential on caster supports like Janna or Nami, but currently their stats aren't that different from those on, say, Talisman of Ascension, or even Sightstone (in fact, they're significantly better). Enchanters should not be made to build defensive stats, they need a stat of their own that they can use to make themselves stronger, mainly by enhancing all of the utility they can bring, and not just their sustain.
Though it's really cool to see proper support itemization in the game.

I get why they are annoying, but I still feel it's a step in the right direction. There is always room for improvement, but I'm especially happy with Locket. I think the concept is a fun addition that can only improve with refinement.

And I admit, fully, that it needs refinement.

It's a step in the right direction in the sense that they're interested in making support more potent. However, it shows just how badly Riot suffers from functional fixedness. They seemingly *cannot* make a strong, functional item without making it "Locket of the Iron Solari-ish", which is exactly what they did.

In my belief, I think more concentrated effects that are more tailored to specific champion play patterns will make for a more rewarding play experience. Like every other role.

I mean, hell, Thresh, Alistar and Braum are still the golden boys of competitive. But now we are actually giving viability to other kinds of support.

Is Redemption over-tuned? Yeah it is, it's too good of a buy for most supports, it's stats probably need to be tweaked so that you're mainly buying it for the active and are sacrificing stats to get it. But it's a step in the right direction.

Effective health, abbreviated to effective with the context that I Was talking about the health stat.

Effective health is health+(health*(armor or mr value/100))
It is used as a method of determining the value of damage one can take before they die. It's actually pretty important to learn if you want to try and build a tank.

The issue comes from fixing a problem by overclocking a possible solution. Sustain isn't "bad" for the game as a concept, but when they mitigate item diversity because of just how useful they are, that's one problem. When it adds up to be this potent even on champions that, on their own, have no business healing or shielding anyone, you get an idea of just how overdone having potent aoe benefits independent of a champ kit really are. Strong sustain that's bound to a kit is balanced around the notion that the kit has its own built-in weaknesses. Strong sustain as a bunch of "one size fits all" items bypasses that fact with extremely convenient stats thrown in as a bonus. You could say "By buying these, you didn't buy those", but these two items are so strong in comparison it's rare that someone gets buyer's remorse over it. If one were to ask me, I'd either remove the items or drastically change how the actives/stats work so they aren't so potent per cast and actually fit a sub set of champions rather than making every support want them.

> [{quoted}](name=chipndip1,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=idhuGnAF,comment-id=000f0000,timestamp=2017-01-08T05:23:32.392+0000)

There's always an optimal build. And as such it "mitigates item diversity". That in and of itself might be a problem but it's definitely not something unique to Locket and Redemption. It's certainly not something you can fix by removing them from the picture.
>When it adds up to be this potent even on champions that, on their own, have no business healing or shielding anyone, you get an idea of just how overdone having potent aoe benefits independent of a champ kit really are. 

Not really, supports have always bought items with individually powerful actives and auras regardless of their QWER because their kits don't scale well with items. (Provided they aren't lane bullies, and even then).

Furthermore, as I said, every champion, regardless of class, benefits from defensive stats.
>Strong sustain that's bound to a kit is balanced around the notion that the kit has its own built-in weaknesses. 

Locket and Redemption have ultimate-like CDs *and* the latter has a huge delay.
>Strong sustain as a bunch of "one size fits all" items bypasses that fact with extremely convenient stats thrown in as a bonus. You could say "By buying these, you didn't buy those", but these two items are so strong in comparison it's rare that someone gets buyer's remorse over it. 

You never had "buyer's remorse" with support items. They're cheap and effective at what they do, that's their thing.
>If one were to ask me, I'd either remove the items or drastically change how the actives/stats work so they aren't so potent per cast and actually fit a sub set of champions rather than making every support want them.

Why? They have counterplay. You can wait them out, tank stats fall off as the game progresses and they have their aforementioned CDs. I don't see an issue with them being regular buys.

The point is that, in a strategy game, it's bad design to have specific strategies be overwhelming in comparison to other possible ones, and this type of massive sustain is nearly impossible to compete with with other items/item combos unless we make them blatantly op as well. On top of that, supports do rely on actives and passives, but it shouldn't be to the point where the actives start to blur the lines of the purpose of your champ pick. What you're saying here is that having one static strategy that's always present for multiple champion classes within a role is healthy and non-problematic, and by that standard things like IBG/Sunfire on every melee champion was also "fine".
